node.title: Congress to vote on raising debt ceiling by $2.5 trillion
node.description: Lifting the debt limit by $2.5 trillion would mean the issue would not come up again until 2023.

node.title: Nurses Say Massachusetts Hospital Ignoring Statewide Order to Halt Elective Surgery
node.description: A nurse claimed patients with brain injuries and broken bones had to wait for surgery as the hospital sees an increase in patients.

node.title: Kitten season sees lots of unwanted pregnancies
node.description: A call from a vet clinic led to Nerida taking in three small kittens found in park bushes. There was no sign of mum anywhere and had heard crying for a number of days. The kittens were very skinny, anaemic, and weighed only 200-250 grams.

node.title: Canegrowers win legal battle against India over sugar subsidies
node.description: After three years, the World Trade Organisation has finally reached a ruling on Australia's complaint against India's sugar subsidies.

node.title: Live Updates: House  to vote on holding Mark Meadows in contempt of Congress
node.description: The House January 6 committee on Monday recommended the former Trump chief of staff be held in contempt.

node.title: Cornell University goes on high alert after finding evidence of the Omicron variant on campus.
node.description: The school moved final exams online, canceled a December graduation ceremony and sports events and barred most visitors from its campus in Ithaca, N.Y.

node.title: Phillip Adams' Family Said He Sought Help From NFL for CTE But Was Denied Before Shooting
node.description: A doctor said Tuesday the former NFL player had "severe" CTE when he allegedly shot and killed six people in April.

node.title: Rain at Greenland Summit Station, Beavers in the Arctic Are Cause for Alarm: Scientists
node.description: It is usually so cold at the Greenland Summit Station that any precipitation falls in the form of snow, making the territory's first rainfall a red flag.

node.title: Ethan Crumbley Charges, Lawsuits Could Change Legal Role of Schools, Parents in Gun Safety
node.description: Legal experts explain to Newsweek how the November 30 shooting may change the responsibility parents and schools may face in future incidents.

node.title: Waitress fired after receiving massive tip
node.description: Grant Wise, a business owner, tipped his two servers a whopping $4,400 – way over the standard 20%. They split it with each other, then were told they had to split it with everyone else.

node.title: Andrew Cuomo ordered to return millions in book proceeds
node.description: Members of the Joint Commission on Public Ethics voted 12-1 for a resolution giving Cuomo 30 days to turn the money over to the New York State Attorney General.

node.title: Review: ‘Wild: A Musical Becoming’ Is Finding Its Footing
node.description: Idina Menzel and a hummable pop score can’t camouflage the fact that this musical is half-baked. Still, it can make for an enjoyable evening, our critic writes.

node.title: An Intimate Look at the Dangerous, Boom-and-Bust Lives of Oil Workers
node.description: In “Sea State,” Tabitha Lasley writes about the time she spent in Scotland investigating life on and around oil rigs.

node.title: That Viral Harry Styles Cardigan Just Got Auctioned as an NFT
node.description: Jonathan Anderson, the designer who made the original sweater, explains how it happened and what's next.

node.title: Omicron will take over London in a matter of hours. Is this a warning for the world?
node.description: Doctors warn the strain is so transmissible it will become the dominant variant not just in the UK, but the world, very quickly, and modelling suggests there could be a million cases of Omicron in Britain by the end of the year.

node.title: Victims of Larry Nassar get record payout
node.description: Hundreds of women abused by former US national gymnastics team doctor Larry Nassar are to receive $US380 million after reaching a settlement with USA Gymnastics.

node.title: Kristen Hayden becomes first Black woman to win national diving title
node.description: "I just want to be a good example for young Black Americans or any minority really for diving in the U.S.," she said.

node.title: Internet Supports Dad Who Told Wife Not To Give Sick Daughter Additional Chores
node.description: "She's damned if she does, damned if she doesn't, because she won't get that healthy childhood off her meds either," a commenter wrote under the Reddit post.

node.title: Ohio City Reverses Decision to Criminalize Abortion After 2 Council Members Lose Election
node.description: The short-lived measure took effect on November 24 and sparked protests from abortion-rights demonstrators who claimed it was unconstitutional.

node.title: Jacob Gaines Gets 4 Years in Prison for Swinging Hammer at U.S. Marshal During Protest
node.description: A judge ruled that Gaines will serve more prison time than his plea deal recommended after hitting a federal officer with a hammer in 2020 in Portland, Oregon.

node.title: 'Inclusivity is about proving opportunities': Why we want you to play wheelchair basketball
node.description: Providing a sport for people with and without a disability to play together is the goal of many school and club sporting environments, but rarely it is considered that to do this. We should start with the inclusion of those with physical impairments first.

node.title: Tasmania's reopening was dependent on its COVID-19 vaccination rate. Here's where it's at
node.description: Tasmania vowed to keep its border closed until it was confident every eligible resident had been offered the chance to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Now it's open again, how does its vaccination efforts compare to the rest of the country?

node.title: 'I think I'm done': How Adam Gilchrist's famous Perth century renewed his love of the game
node.description: It has gone down as one of the greatest innings in Ashes history, but Adam Gilchrist has revealed just how close he was to pulling the pin on his career before his famous Perth ton in 2006.

node.title: Finished Succession? Try these other shows from the same writers
node.description: With Succession's third season coming to an exhilarating close, you'd be forgiven for being at a loss on what to watch next. Aside from reliving the drama all over again, check out these other titles from Succession's writers.

node.title: 'Spreading like wildfire': Nightclub COVID cluster's six days of turbocharged infections
node.description: It's taken just six days for the Newcastle nightclub COVID-19 cluster to surpass last year's northern beaches outbreak. This is why it's spreading so quickly.

node.title: International students return to Australia warning of a reputation tarnished abroad
node.description: International students and skilled migrants can once again enter Australia without an exemption as the country's tough border policies soften slightly.

node.title: Australia's connections to British slavery have long been buried. It's time to update the history books
node.description: Many Australians are unaware that some prominent early settlers had links to British slavery. Telling these stories provides a better collective sense of the past.

node.title: NSW health report card reveals true impact of the COVID Delta outbreak
node.description: The latest NSW health report card finds the ambulance service and emergency departments hit record performance lows at the height of the Delta outbreak, despite the government claiming the system was coping well under the pressure of the pandemic.

node.title: 'Our deepest regret': Major disability service provider apologises for violence, abuse in group homes
node.description: One of Australia's biggest disability service providers apologises for incidents of violence, abuse and neglect in two of its group homes, telling a royal commission they "could have done more" to help residents.

node.title: Stuck in mud, four giant 'thunder birds' died. Some 50,000 years later, their bones tell a painful story
node.description: Well-preserved fossils show some individuals in a population of Australia's "thunder birds" were suffering a painful bone disease when they died. But what was the real cause of their eventual extinction?
